text: For me the game that made the greatest impact on me was Warcraft III: ROC & TFT. During the golden age of custom game development. When DOTA was in its infancy and people expressed their creativity through the world editor. I made my own custom game and the process of it all was what inspired me to be a computer programmer. It was the birthplace of my love of computer logic. I would literally be online for 24+ hours playing custom games and chatting online and being a part of a clan and the whole community before everything turned to shit with the bots hosting more games than there were people online. If you try to play now, there are only a handful of custom games that get any attention, whereas my downloads folder in the golden era had literally hundreds of custom games and each one saw some play from time to time. I would kill to go back in time and do it all again.

text:
When I played my first video game (Super Mario Bros for NES) I was about 5 or 6 and my mind was BLOWN!!! I thought it all looked so real and I had full control! It was incredible! Needless to say I have these great memories about how real so many games looked (Mega Man, TMNT, Zelda, Sonic, Pirates, Street Fighter). I grew up as the graphics got better, but I swear my imagination filled in all the missing pixels for those old games in a way that no new console can do.

THAT SAID: The first time I ever got stoned I went to Fred Meyer and they had the NEW Mario 64. First time ever playing a real 3D game! First time being stoned! It melts my mind just talking about it. When I finally got my hands on my very own N64 I beat through that sucker twice in a row (all 120 stars!) without hesitation.

Thanks for posting and giving me a chance to reminisce!

text:
Final Fantasy 4 (2 to those of us who played it back then) really demonstrated to me how a video game can actually tell a story; how the journey can be as satisfying as the destination, how simple pixels and some text can become living, breathing people with personalities.

author: JoylessAlbatross

text:
these are supposed to be replies to myself, but youtube sucks at doing that.

- super smash bros melee. this is not even a game to me anymore. i play it "competitively" so it's bigger than that, and more of a social thing. i've made many good friends through this game, traveled to different countries (well, from canada to the US), and just gotten so much more out of it than the creators could have hoped for. i don't know what they did to make this game so intensely fun, but i thank them.
author: JoylessAlbatross

text: Super Metroid probably had the biggest impact on me, in that it was one huge inter-connected world, and it was set up that I was free to explore it in any way I wanted. Never before had a game felt so expansive. The music and graphics made an atmospheric experience I had never felt before too. Also, Lunar: Silver Star Story was the first game to really get me interested in the story and characters. I had played RPGs before, but they never made me feel they had real emotion in their script.
author: TheKnightOfNee

text:
Incidentally, my dad is also the reason i played secret of evermore =) i glanced at it on a shelf one day, but didn't pick it up; he thought it looked interesting, and upon looking at the case more closely (this was a small store without the actual box art) i agreed.

- super mario rpg. one time i broke both my wrists, and among my first thoughts was "I hope I can still play super mario rpg." turns out i could, it just hurt a bunch. this is another near flawless game.
author: JoylessAlbatross

text:
some of the more important games to me:

- ff7. this is the deepest game i've ever played. i played it again recently, and though i can see its flaws more easily now, it still gets to me on a level most video games don't; usually that place is reserved for movies and music.

- super metroid. this game is perfect. it is highly atmospheric. it's also the only game my dad has ever helped me get past a puzzle on. now, maybe 10 years later, i can beat it in under an hour.
author: JoylessAlbatross

text: I feel the same way about SM64.  The first console I had was a NES but the first game that truly had an impact on me was Goldeneye 64.  I loved other games before it but Goldeneye was the first multiplayer game in my memory that all of my friends and myself would play nonstop all weekend and have great fun destroying each other on.  Never got old.  Nine years later and we still play from time to time when everyone is in town.  Top 2 players play on, bottom 2 surrender controllers, rinse/repeat.
